The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, amends provisions related to the Interagency Committee on Dam Safety by focusing on coordination and information exchange among Federal agencies for implementing dam safety guidelines. The National Dam Safety Program, established by the Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, focuses on coordination and information exchange among Federal agencies to implement dam safety guidelines. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 amends Section 8 to update duties and objectives related to improving dam safety in the United States. The Director is required to prepare a strategic plan with goals, priorities, and cooperation with governmental entities in all states. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 updates Section 8 by adding objectives to develop technical assistance materials and coordinate national efforts to improve dam safety in the United States. It also includes provisions for implementing an implementation plan and dam safety training. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 updates Section 8 by amending subsections and providing assistance for State Dam Safety Programs. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 updates Section 8 by amending subsections and providing assistance for State Dam Safety Programs, including criteria for eligibility and improvements in security measures. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 updates Section 8 by amending subsections related to operating procedures and the establishment of a Board to monitor dam safety in the United States. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 amends Section 8 by updating the membership structure of the Board overseeing dam safety. Voting membership is clarified, with 5 members selected from State dam safety officials and 1 member representing the private sector. Nonvoting membership roles and work groups are also defined. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 updates the membership structure of the Board overseeing dam safety. The Director may invite nonvoting members from National Laboratories, Federal or State agencies, or dam safety experts to participate in meetings. The Board's duties include encouraging effective programs for dam safety nationwide. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 updates the Board's membership structure to ensure coordination among Federal and State dam safety agencies. Members of the Board can be reimbursed for travel expenses by FEMA while away from home or regular place of business in the performance of services. SEC. 4. RESEARCH.

Amends Section 9(a) to cooperate with the Board, develop and support information resources systems for dam safety, and guide public policy for dam safety engineering, security, and management.

SEC. 5. DAM SAFETY TRAINING. SEC. 5. DAM SAFETY TRAINING. The Act is amended to provide training for State dam safety staff and inspectors upon request. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Section 11 is amended by removing subsection (a) and following text. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. The Act is amended to increase annual amounts to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Allocation changes include updating references from section 8(f) to section 8(e) and removing references to States needing assistance under section 8(f). Research, dam safety training, and staff provisions are also revised. The Act is amended to increase annual amounts for research, dam safety training, and staff provisions. $1,500,000 is authorized for research, $500,000 for dam safety training, and $600,000 for staff employment for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2006.
